major_name: Mechanical Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Energy Conversion Fall 2024
Design of fossil-fuel central power plants, including boiler efficiency calculations and advanced steam and binary cycles.
Review of atomic physics including fission and fusion energy.
Design of nuclear fission power plants including design of reactor core for critical conditions, fuel cycles and radiation hazards.
Design considerations for solar energy conversion devices including: availability of solar energy, solar-thermal converters, thermal storage and photovoltaics.
Principles of fuel cells and some aspects of their design.
We look at the way Canada, and the world, use energy, where the energy comes from, the finite nature of some reserves, and the impact of this energy use on the environment.
Sustainability and the security of energy supply are also discussed.
We review conventional energy systems from an efficiency and global warming perspective.
From the study of these various factors, it will become clear that new energy technologies will need to be adopted in the future.

We then study energy conversion devices and systems not studied in previous courses: for example, nuclear reactors, MHD, fuel cells, solar energy conversion(s), wind energy conversion, co-generation, hydroelectricity, ethanol, methanol, geothermal, ocean thermal, wave, tidal, thermoelectric.
The objective is to broaden the students’ understanding of energy, both in a technical sense and in an environmental and socio-economic sense.
6 Entropy and Availability
8 Coal and Combustion
9 Nuclear Energy
11 Ethanol for Vehicles
12 Methanol for Vehicles
14 Solar Energy
17 Wind Power
18 Wave Power
19 Tidal Power
22 Thermoelectric
Students must research in depth one topic in energy conversion and present their findings in a 7500 - 10000 word or so (~15-20 pages, … … or so) report.
Project topics will be allocated in the first few lectures on a first-come, first-served basis.
To select a topic, send me an email request, with alternatives in case your primary request is taken.

However, the socio-economic and environmental aspects of the topic, and some indication of the magnitude of its possible impact on the demand for energy and on global-warming should also be considered.

topics: DWE 2402
P. Enrique

Metallurgy of welding of steels (carbon, microalloy, low alloy and stainless steels), cast irons, aluminum-based, copper-based, nickel-based, cobalt-based, titanium-based and other alloys, (including dissimilar combinations) to explain the effects of welding processes and conditions (including post-weld heat treating) on microstructure and properties; causes and prevention of defects and deficiencies which can occur in different alloys, including porosity, cracking, embrittlement (hydrogen, temper, strain aging, ductile-brittle transition temperatures), overaging; metallurgy of soldered and brazed joints.

Understand how welding process parameters influence all of the above concepts
Understand how post-process heat treatments influence microstructures

course_name: ME540 - Fundamentals in Neural and Rehabilitation Engineering (0.50)
major_name: Mechanical Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Fundamentals in Neural and Rehabilitation Engineering Fall 2024
DWE 2402
DWE 2402
DWE 2402
DWE 2402
DWE 2402
Introduction to the field of neural and rehabilitation engineering (NRE).

Topics include describing common neurological and musculoskeletal injuries, related neural and rehabilitation engineering approaches to address disabilities, and the development of a design framework for synthesizing a novel neural and rehabilitation engineering approach.
Critical concepts in clinical research design to meet current regulatory, ethical, and practice policies will be studied.
Describe and apply evidence-based medicine (EBM) concepts applied to NRE.
Evaluate and criticize existing neural and rehabilitation engineering (NRE) approaches.
Synthesize and disseminate a novel innovation to solve a self-selected problem in NRE.
There are 12 graduate attributes total and collection of these attributes is pertinent in ensuring our engineering programs remain accredited.
This is an upper year elective course introducing the field of neural and rehabilitation engineering (NRE) by exposing students to the key problems and current engineering approaches.
The first half of the course will focus on describing common neurological and musculoskeletal injuries and related NRE approaches to address disabilities.
Subsequent classes will examine critical concepts in clinical research design to meet current regulatory, ethical, and practice policies.
At the end of the term, students will pitch their proposal to a panel of judges, representing clinical and industry stakeholders.

Hands-on labs will teach students the integration of mechanical, electrical, and software systems through building a soft robotic finger prosthesis along with inertial measurement units, electromyography and electroencephalography.

course_name: ME548 - Numerical Control of Machine Tools 1 (0.50)
major_name: Mechanical Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Optimum cutting conditions.
Laboratory work provides hands-on experience in tool path generation, machining, and measurements of cutting forces and vibration.

This course aims to provide students with a background in the operating principles of CNC machine tools, NC part programming, CAD/CAM software, mechanics of metal cutting operations (such as turning, milling, and drilling), and the dynamic behavior of machine tools under the influence of cutting forces originating from the machining process.
Write and interpret G-code for three-axis CNC machining.
Model feed drives and analyze their performance based on torque and power requirements.
Use basic control methods to tune servo drives based on time and frequency domain requirements as well as desired dimensional accuracy of produced parts.
Understand the use of and differences between the oblique and orthogonal cutting models for describing metal cutting mechanics.
Calculate cutting forces in three orthogonal axes for milling, turning, and drilling processes for a given set of process parameters.
Describe and analyze multi-degree-of-freedom vibrations that occur in machine tool structures using modal analysis.
Describe the causes of regenerative chatter in machining and predict its occurrence based on machine-tool dynamics and process parameters using an orthogonal cutting model.
Use related software for designing and optimizing CNC operations (MasterCAM, MachPro), performing measurements on a CMM machine (MCOSMOS), and analyzing machine dynamics (tap testing with CutPro).
Operating principles, components, and control of CNC machine tools
Automatic NC code generation with CAD/CAM software (MasterCAM)
Afterwards, they will write a CMM inspection program and use the CMM to measure the errors in their part.
Orthogonal and oblique cutting
Mechanics of milling, turning, and drilling
Tool wear and breakage
Selection of optimum machining conditions
Students will measure actual cutting forces during a milling operation using a dynamometer.
Static and Dynamic Deformations in Machining (~11 hr)
Dimensional form errors in turning, boring, and milling
Structural vibrations of machine tools
Forced and self-excited (chatter) vibrations in machining
Project 3 (7%): Modal testing and analysis of a linear motion stage.
Students will measure the accelerance frequency response function (FRF) of a linear motion stage at 5 different points.

topics: Notice of Recording

Selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air-and geothermal-source heat pumps.
Course Overview: Achieving significant reductions in building energy consumption will be important in efforts to deal with the environmental and socioeconomic impacts of energy use.
The energy used by heating, ventilating, and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems represents a large portion of the energy consumption of most commercial, institutional, and residential buildings.

This course will introduce selected topics in HVAC systems design, with focus on energy-efficiency and environmental-sustainability: heating and cooling distribution using air-, water-, and refrigerant-based systems; constant- and variable-flow systems; heat- and energy-recovery systems; vapor-compression heat-pump systems, including air- and geothermal-source heat pumps.

Recommended Preparation: It is strongly recommended that students have engaged in prior study of introductory concepts in thermodynamics, heat transfer, and fluid mechanics, including analysis of refrigeration cycles and basic psychrometrics.
Students without this background are expected to undertake additional study to acquire sufficient competency in each topic.
Perform simple thermodynamic calculations for selected HVAC components and systems.

topics: Power Electronics and Motor Drives Fall 2024
E-mail: mkazerani@uwaterloo.ca
Analysis, design and control of power electronic converters, principles of operation and control of DC and special-purpose motors, power electronics-based control of DC and special-purpose motors.

This course covers a wide range of materials on power electronic and motor drives, including terminal characteristics of power semiconductor devices, switch losses, power electronic converter topologies (diode rectifiers, thyristor converters, DC/DC converters and DC/AC converters) and their corresponding control techniques, waveform quality, L-C low-pass filter design, power factor correction, DC motors and their corresponding speed control and electrical braking techniques, Induction motors and their corresponding speed control and electrical braking techniques, special-purpose motors, and computer simulation of power electronic converters and motor drives.
Describe terminal characteristics of power semiconductor devices; Select a proper switch for a given application
Calculate switch losses as the first step in identifying thermal management requirements
Describe structure and analyze operation of diode rectifiers, thyristor converters, DC/DC converters and DC/AC converters
Design DC/DC converters and DC/AC converters
Describe and implement control techniques for DC/DC converters and DC/AC converters
Design L-C low-pass filters for power electronic converters
Describe the concept of power factor correction (PFC) and a well-known PFC technique
Describe the structure, speed control and electrical braking techniques of DC motors
Describe the structure, speed control and electrical braking techniques of induction motors
Describe the structure and basics of control of special-purpose motors
Simulate power electronic converters and motor drives using PSIM (a commercial software tool for simulation of power electronic systems)

IGBT and IGCT, Introduction to Wide-Bandgap devices, Switch losses)

Electrical Sensors and Safety Systems

ECE 457A
• Huda Diab Abdulgalil: Email hdiababd@uwaterloo.ca
The course starts by addressing the ill-structured problems and need for computational intelligence methods.
It introduces the concepts of heuristics and their use in conjunction with search methods, solving problems using heuristics and metaheuristics, constraints satisfaction.
The course also introduces the concepts of co-operation and adaptations and how they are influencing new methods for solving complex problems.
The course starts by illustrating how the concepts of co-operation and adaptation are manifested in nature and how such models are inspiring new types of solutions methods.

Topics to be covered include search algorithms, game playing, constraints satisfaction, meta-heuristics, evolutionary computing methods, swarm intelligence, ant-colony algorithms, particle swarm methods, adaptive and learning algorithms and the use of these algorithms in solving continuous and discrete problems that arise in engineering applications.

Profiling computer systems; bottlenecks, Amdahl's law.
View requirements for ECE 459
Many modern software systems must process large amounts of data, either in the form of huge data sets or vast numbers of (concurrent) transactions.
This course introduces students to techniques for profiling, rearchitecting, and implementing software systems that can handle industrial-sized inputs.
These techniques will enable you to design and build critical software infrastructure, especially in an age of Big Data.
While you may have seen some of these ideas in the context of operating systems (ECE350/SE350/CS350/MTE241) and concurrency (ECE252/CS343), this course gives you tools to make code run faster.

topics: Notice of Recording
Introduction to Complex Systems Winter 2025
Professor Paul Fieguth pfieguth@uwaterloo.ca Office Hours: Mondays 4-5pm in E7-6338

The overwhelming majority of societal, ecological and climate issues of pressing importance are complex systems; nonlinear dynamic interacting systems poorly characterized by linear analyses and Gaussian statistics.
This course introduces the mathematics needed to understand such interactions, including nonlinear dynamics, critical and bifurcation behaviours, large-scale systems and power-law distributions.

The mathematical methods will be motivated by extensive examples and case studies such as global warming, energy shortages, desertification, overpopulation, poverty, and economic instability, to be investigated from a systems engineering perspective that will connect mathematical concepts to real-world examples.
Understand the assumptions and limitations behind linear dynamic / Gaussian systems
Understand the mathematical properties of nonlinear dynamic / power-law systems
Be able to abstract / generalize the impacts and implications of nonlinear systems
Be able to draw connections between macroscopic socio-environmental systems

topics: User Centred Design Methods Winter 2025
UCD Mentors Pronouns Email Office Extra Help
This course approaches the design of tasks, tools, products, and systems from a user-centered design perspective.
Emphasis is on the human factors and usability methods, and techniques that can and should be applied throughout the iterative design process.
Major topics include user research methods for usability and user experience, inspection methods, user testing, applied statistical analysis.
SYDE 548 (UCD Methods) approaches the design of tasks, tools, products, and systems from a user-centered design perspective.
Emphasis is on the human factors and usability methods, and techniques that can and should be applied throughout the iterative design process.
Major topics include user research methods for usability and user experience, inspection methods, user testing, and applied statistical analysis.
SYDE 548 User-Centred Design Methods is a technical elective.
It builds from earlier SYDE core courses in design (SYDE-BME 161 Introduction to Design, SYDE-BME 162 Human Factors in Design, and SYDE-BME 361 Engineering Design).
Motivated students willing to become familiar with basic human factors engineering can participate and contribute to course activities.
Whether you are interested in becoming a UCD specialist, a certified ergonomist, or just want to be a wise designer or consumer, this course will supply you with a range of practical tools (methods).
Our “In-class” sessions are used as workshops for interactions and hands-on skill development with different UR methods.

major_name: Mechanical Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Physiological Systems and Biomedical Design Winter 2025
Email: maud.gorbet@uwaterloo.ca

The structure, functions, and properties of major physiological systems (e.g., musculoskeletal, nervous, cardiovascular, and respiratory) will be presented in relation to modelling physiological systems and the design of biomedical devices (imaging, assistive, and diagnostic).
The structure, functions and properties of some of the major physiological systems (musculoskeletal, nervous, and cardiovascular) will be presented with an engineering science perspective.

Strong emphasis will be given to mechanical, electrical, chemical and biological properties of tissues and their relation to measurements, modeling human systems, and the design of biomedical devices (assistive, orthopedic and diagnostic).
Various aspects of physiological system dysfunctions and how they influence measurements and design of medical devices will be discussed.

Develop an engineering perspective toward understanding biological functions
Develop critical thinking skills for solving biomedical problems and designing sound biomedical technologies

The numbers in the parathesis refer to the Engineering Graduate Attributes defined by the Canadian Engineering Accreditation Board (CEAB):

A knowledge base for engineering: Demonstrated competence in university-level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the program.
Problem analysis: An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

Investigation: An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.

Design: An ability to design solutions for complex, open-ended engineering problems and to design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate attention to health and safety risks, applicable standards, and economic, environmental, cultural, and societal considerations.
Communication skills: An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.

Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking, and listening, and the ability to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.
Professionalism: An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.
Impact of engineering on society and the environment: An ability to analyze social and environmental aspects of engineering activities.

Such ability includes an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society, the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions, and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.

Life-long learning: An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world in ways sufficient to maintain their competence and to allow them to contribute to the advancement of knowledge.

View requirements for MTE 320
This course provides an in-depth study of the principles and applications of actuators and power electronics in modern engineering systems.
It combines foundational knowledge in circuit analysis and electromagnetic theory with practical skills for analyzing and operating electromechanical systems.
Topics include the fundamentals of AC circuits, magnetic circuits, transformers, DC machines, and power electronics, with a focus on their use in motor control and power conversion.
The course also includes a comprehensive laboratory component that reinforces theoretical concepts through hands-on experiments.
Students will work in teams to enhance their understanding of actuators and power electronic systems.
Understanding AC circuit concepts, including phasor notation, power factor correction, and magnetic circuits with losses, to analyze electric systems.
Understand the operation, characteristics, and control techniques of single-phase transformers and DC machines, including efficiency, regulation, and speed control.
Analyze power electronic converters, including semiconductor devices and DC/DC converters, for various applications.
Implement speed control techniques for DC motors using power electronic converters to optimize performance.
Develop strong problem-solving and innovative thinking skills to address the evolving needs of actuators' operation and control
Acquire a solid foundation in the theoretical and practical aspects of electric drives and control, preparing for a successful career in electrical engineering.
1 AC Circuits: Single-phase circuits, phasor notation, average and RMS values, complex power, and power factor correction.
2 Magnetic Circuits: Electric and magnetic circuit analysis, magnetic field generation, induced voltages and forces, and loss mechanisms.

Motor Control: Basics of motor speed control using power electronic converters for DC motor performance optimization.

Lectures and tutorials are held in person and attendance is expected at all sessions for learning and skill development.
Jan 20th and Jan 22nd  Lab 1 – Introduction and setup (watch Learn for signup instructions closer to)
Lab 2 – Synchronization Techniques
Course Introduction An introduction to the teaching team, course expectations, deliverables, marking scheme, and a very brief introduction to interfacing concepts.
Embedded Systems A review of fundamentals of embedded systems and the terminology associated with embedded systems.
Embedded Design Model An introduction to the embedded design model used to develop a system for the remainder of the course.
Embedded Software An overview of they key differences between software for embedded systems and general software development.
Synchronization, Data Generation and Data Transfer A model for analyzing synchronization behaviour and performance and examples of synchronization analysis.
Buses - Data Transfer A comparison of the functional behaviour and timing behaviour of synchronous, asynchronous, and partially interlocked asynchronous.
Parallel Interfacing A detailed examination of the design of parallel interfaces.
This includes an examination of the role of the interface in matching bus timing and signaling characteristics with a device's timing and signaling characteristics.
Analog Interfacing An introduction to digital-to-analog interfacing, analog-to-digital interfacing, and sample-and-hold circuitry.
This includes a comparison of asynchronous communication techniques and synchronous techniques as well as the protocols for serial communication.

Buses - Arbitration A brief examination of alternatives for bus arbitration including a discussion of the operation and characteristics of daisy chained and non-daisy chained bus arbitration techniques.
A brief examination of direct memory access including a discussion of hardware design implications, software implications, and system performance.
Security and Ethics An overview of common security terminology and why it has become increasingly important for embedded systems.
The ethical implications of today’s embedded systems applications will also be discussed.
